Issues.Title: Min-width for tiling?
Issues.Body:
This is about Bulma, the CSS framework.

I think I have found a bug but I'm not sure if it's a bug or purposefully set that way.

I'm using Bulma 0.7.2

My browser is Firefox but it is identical in chrome.



### Overview of the problem

When setting the variable `$body-min-width`, this doesn't seem to prevent the tiles from changing as the website gets smaller.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a tiling layout (mine uses a 8-width and 4-width tile)
2. Set the min-width (I'm using 1024px)
3. Make the browser smaller than 1024px and note the tiling does not keep layout, it continues to change at certain breakpoints.


### Expected behavior

What I expected was that once smaller than 1024px the website would no longer change, but just get a scroll horizontal scroll bar.

Again, as I stated above, perhaps this is on purpose,but I just wanted to confirm. I'm not sure how else with Bulma one would create a min width that prevents the website from dynamically changing beyond a point.

NOTE that the website does get a horizontal scroll bar (if you set `$body-overflow-x: scroll;`) and that other things don't change but the tiling seems to be relative to the viewport width and therefore continues to change.

### Actual behavior

Refer to step 3 of "steps to reproduce"

### Sidenote

Huge fan of Bulma, thank you so much for making this awesome framework, let me know if there is anything else you need me to explain about the issue and I will happily.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Min-width for tiling?" (#2528)

Issues.Title: Responsive margin + paddings
Issues.Body:
### Responsive margins + paddings

I am sure that I am not the first one who needs a different margin and padding setting on tablet and on desktop devices etc.

So, it would be cool if you can do the following thing:

`<section class="section is-marginless-vertical-mobile has-margin-vertical-tablet"></section> `

By default, there are only these entries in the helper.sass:
```
.is-marginless
  margin: 0 !important

.is-paddingless
  padding: 0 !important
```

I've extended this having such things like:

```
is-marginless-tablet
is-paddingless-vertical
has-padding-horizontal
has-margin-vertical-desktop
```
If you don't need all variations (there are a lot...), you can control this by two arrays.

I attach the sass file and a sample output with all variations.

If this is also helpful for anybody else, I can do a pull request.

[margin_sample.css.txt](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/files/3276839/margin_sample.css.txt)

[margin_responsive.sass.txt](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/files/3276843/margin_responsive.sass.txt)


Best wishes,
Georg.

_PS: I luv Bulma!!!!_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Responsive margin + paddings" (#2527)

Issues.Title: Add .is-title-adjacent helper -- support for arbitrarily moving elements closer to titles (Fixes #2346)
Issues.Body: This is a **new feature**. Hi. This is my first time opening a pull request in Bulma! 👋🏻 The .is-title-adjacent helper adds the ability to arbitrarily move any element which is below a title or a subtitle closer to that title or subtitle, in the same way that a subtitle automatically moves closer to a title. ### Proposed solution Some websites like to have things like bylines, post datetimes, or other things kept close to the post title area. This helper makes it easier to do this in Bulma without writing custom code. It fixes Issue #2346, which I filed in February. ### Tradeoffs The way this is written, it shouldn't impact those who have already written custom code to do this same thing, so that's thankfully *not* a tradeoff here. I don't see any reason why it adds any significant tradeoffs, though, of course, for more specific use cases, some users will continue to create their own custom classes. ### Testing Done The changes I've made are small, so they seem to work as intended. As I'm a first-time contributor, I wanted to submit this pull request with the intent of making sure that there isn't something I'm overlooking, but given the tests done both on my personal website and while updating the docs, things seem to look good. On my personal website, before the changes: My personal website, after the changes: Screenshot of my modifications to the documentation: ![Screenshot 2019-06-05 13 49 20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/280610/58978062-0d09c180-8799-11e9-97c4-63ad6115d38c.png) ### Changelog updated? Yes. *edit: Updated screenshots with slightly smaller, better-looking (maybe) ones with the same content.*

Issues.Title: Fix inconsistent input[disabled] color in Safari. Fixes #2355
Issues.Body: This is a **bugfix**. ### Proposed solution Safari is rendering `disabled` input fields with faded text. Instead of the Bulma default `#7a7a7a` (48% luminosity), the input text renders at `#cecece` (81% luminosity). Multiple users reported confusion, thinking the ` value=` was instead `placeholder=` text, because it was so faded. Bulma is [already choosing to override the default `` text `color`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/ff8c4c18accf2c0094aa77945b1d2180ac927159/sass/elements/form.sass#L67). That setting simply isn't taking effect in Safari & iOS Safari. Screenshots of the bug (top correct, bottom incorrect): This PR fixes it. ### Tradeoffs This adds a bit of browser-specific attributes to the codebase. A case could be made that's better handled by `normalize.css`. ### Testing Done Confirmed to work in production. ### Changelog updated? No.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fix inconsistent input[disabled] color in Safari. Fixes #2355" (#2517)

Issues.Title: 0.7.5: Wrapping .tile.is-child in <a> element breaks tile width sizing, possibly the tiles entirely
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **bug** in **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.5
My **browser** is: Safari 12.1.1
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**. ✅

### Description

Sometimes it's necessary to wrap an entire .tile.is-child in an `<a>` element. When this is done, though, it appears to cease to function properly as a tile; it loses its ability to be sized using the .is-x column sizing scheme and won't size its height according to the other tiles in its row.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a tile structure resembling this:
```
div class="tile is-ancestor"
  div class="tile is-parent"
    a href="#" rel="Text"
      article class="tile is-child is-4 notification is-warning"
        p class="title" Some text
        p class="subtitle" some text
  div class="tile is-parent"
    a href="#" rel="Text"
      article class="tile is-child is-4 notification is-info"
        p class="title" Some other text
        p class="subtitle" some text
  div class="tile is-parent"
    a href="#" rel="Text"
      article class="tile is-child is-4 notification is-success"
        p class="title" Even more text
        p class="subtitle" some text
```
2. Observe.

### Expected behavior

The tiles will appear as expected, and also be functional links.

### Actual behavior

While having the appropriate y-coordinates that they otherwise should, the tiles fail to adhere to the specified default width, and the tiles shrink to fit around the content; the width specifically shrinks to fit around the widest character in the text, leaving each tile looking long and tall, like an unfurled banner. The heights of each tile no longer line up.

### Commentary

Switch the "is-4" class from the .is-child divs to the .is-parent divs and observe the change in behavior. Note how while the tiles are still shrinking to fit around the content, it no longer appears strange as the tiles aren't shrinking on their x-axis.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "0.7.5: Wrapping .tile.is-child in <a> element breaks tile width sizing, possibly the tiles entirely" (#2506)

I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? ❌ There is an issue #2293 opened by @jp06 dealing with this problem from December, but the user stopped at figuring out that wrapping each .is-child in an .is-parent fixed their issue instead of pushing for further clarity for the docs or bug fixes.

### Description

The documentation leads users to believe that they do not have to surround each individual .tile.is-child element with its own corresponding .tile.is-parent element in order for a gap to display between tiles -- on the page, gaps are shown between tiles where multiple .tile.is-child elements are housed within one .tile.is-parent. However, in Bulma 0.7.5, each individual .tile.is-child needs to be housed within its own .tile.is-parent (where .is-vertical is not being used; it was not tested here and its effect here is currently unknown as it has as of yet been unnecessary for my project) for gaps to show up.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a set of three tiles structured as such:
```
# .tile.is-ancestor
|----# .tile.is-parent
     |----# .tile.is-child is-4 notification is-warning
          |----# p.title
          |----# p.subtitle
     |----# .tile.is-child is-4 notification is-warning
          |----# p.title
          |----# p.subtitle
     |----# .tile.is-child is-4 notification is-warning
          |----# p.title
          |----# p.subtitle
```
2. Observe.

### Expected behavior

As intimated by the documentation, a gap should appear between the three tiles.

### Actual behavior

No gap appears between each tile.

### Commentary

Add a surrounding .tile.is-parent to each individual .tile.is-child element. You will find that the gaps reappear. The docs do not seem to make clear that this is necessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "0.7.5: Tile gaps don't work unless each .is-child is wrapped in its own .is-parent, docs unclear" (#2505)

Issues.Title: Keep deprecated form location working
Issues.Body:
Use the old form.sass location as an alias for the new files.

<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **bugfix**.

The latest version 0.7.5 breaks all existing code that is importing `sass/elements/form.sass`.
I think we should only do this with `0.8.0` at the earliest.

### Proposed solution

Keep `sass/elements/form.sass` as an alias for `sass/form/_all.sass`.

### Tradeoffs

This way we can still keep the depreciation warning, but do not have to right away break so much.

### Testing Done

I have tested this change in my own application which uses bulma extensively and directly includes the individual sass files, `form.sass` in particular.
In contrast to release `0.7.5`, where the form classes are missing now, this change makes all styles work correctly.
The deprecation message is displayed for both during compilation.
